## Information about 'Decode the anatomy of facial expression'

### Explanation
'Decode the anatomy of facial expression' is a comprehensive guide to understanding facial mechanics and the Facial Action Coding System (FACS). It involves breaking down facial motion using visual-first approaches and multidisciplinary insights.

### Purpose
The purpose is to simplify the complexity of facial motion for professionals, likely in fields such as film, game, and tech, by providing detailed breakdowns and resources.

### Relevant Links
- [Explore the full course](https://melindaozel.com/services/lectures-training/facs-cram-session/)
- [FACS Reference Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/facs-cheat-sheet/)
- [Viseme Reference Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-cheat-sheet/)
- [ARkit to FACS Reference Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/arkit-to-facs-cheat-sheet/)
- [Facial Capture Tips](https://melindaozel.com/facial-expressions-facial-data-capture/)
- [Visemes & Muted Speech](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-variability-gritted-teeth-muted-speech/)
- [/p/ /b/ /m/ Bilabial Visemes](https://melindaozel.com/m-b-p-bilabial-visemes/)
- [Soft Tissues & Skin Squish](https://melindaozel.com/squishy-faces-expressions/)
- ['It's All In the Eyes' and Other Lies](https://melindaozel.com/its-all-in-the-eyes-and-other-lies/)

### Instructions
The webpage does not provide explicit instructions for 'Decode the anatomy of facial expression.' However, it offers various resources and links to explore related topics in detail.

### Phone Numbers
No phone numbers are mentioned on the webpage.

### People Names
- Melinda Ozel: The expert behind the content, specializing in facial motion and FACS.

### Addresses
No physical addresses are provided on the webpage. However, there are links to Melinda Ozel's professional profiles:
- [Twitter](https://x.com/melindaozel)
- [Instagram](https://instagram.com/manicexpression)
- [LinkedIn](https://linkedin.com/in/melindaozel)

### Key Features
- Visual-first breakdowns of facial expressions
- Multidisciplinary insights into facial mechanics and FACS
- Various free and premium resources for learning, including reference sheets and study guides
- Topics range from facial muscle variation to animating eyes in smiles and visualizing phonemes for lipsync

### Other Relevant Details
- Melinda Ozel has 13 years of experience in expression tracking, facial animation, and AI lipsync.
- The website offers premium resources and training services for professionals.
- The content is trusted by top brands in film, game, and tech.

Attachments:

semantic_path: https://melindaozel.com/Viseme Reference Sheet
browser_content:
## Comprehensive Information about 'Viseme Reference Sheet'

### Explanation
The webpage https://melindaozel.com/viseme-variability-gritted-teeth-muted-speech/ discusses the concept of visemes and their variability in speech, particularly in the context of facial animation and audio-to-face technologies. Visemes are defined as canonical shapes assigned to groups of phonemes to simplify lipsync studies. However, the 'Viseme Reference Sheet' is not directly explained on the visited pages.

### Relevant Links
- [Viseme Cheat Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-cheat-sheet/): A resource provided by the author for more rigid and clock-like examples of visemes.
- Premium Resources: https://melindaozel.com/premium-resources/
- All About Lipsync: https://melindaozel.com/all-about-lipsync-videos-obsidian/
- FACS Cheat Sheet: https://melindaozel.com/facs-cheat-sheet/

### Instructions
The article does not provide direct instructions for using a viseme reference sheet but discusses the challenges and complexities of visemes in speech.

### Key Features
- Visemes are not as reliable as widely believed due to variations in speech articulation.
- Certain phoneme groups, such as /p/, /b/, and /m/, are considered more robust and typically grouped into the same viseme category (closed lip shape).
- The actual viseme forms of phonemes can be extremely variable, making accurate simulation of speech challenging.

### Other Relevant Details
- The author, Melinda Ozel, is a facial motion expert specializing in the Facial Action Coding System (FACS) and facial anatomy, with experience in expression tracking, facial animation, and AI lipsync.
- The article references a specific example from the TV series 'Severance' where a character's gritted teeth and muted articulation style affect the expected viseme shapes.
- The complexity of human speech and the variability of visemes are highlighted as significant challenges in creating accurate and natural-looking speech simulations.

Attachments:

## Comprehensive Information about 'Viseme Reference Sheet'

### Explanation
The webpage discusses the concept of visemes and their variability in speech, particularly in the context of facial animation and audio-to-face technologies. Visemes are defined as canonical shapes assigned to groups of phonemes to simplify lipsync studies. However, the "right" viseme shape is relative and depends on various factors beyond coarticulation.

### Relevant Links
- [Viseme Cheat Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-cheat-sheet/): A resource provided by the author for more rigid and clock-like examples of visemes.

### Instructions
The article does not provide direct instructions for using a viseme reference sheet but discusses the challenges and complexities of visemes in speech.

### Key Features
- Visemes are not as reliable as widely believed due to variations in speech articulation.
- Certain phoneme groups, such as /p/, /b/, and /m/, are considered more robust and typically grouped into the same viseme category (closed lip shape).
- The actual viseme forms of phonemes can be extremely variable, making accurate simulation of speech challenging.

### Other Relevant Details
- The author, Melinda Ozel, is a facial motion expert specializing in the Facial Action Coding System (FACS) and facial anatomy, with experience in expression tracking, facial animation, and AI lipsync.
- The article references a specific example from the TV series "Severance" where a character's gritted teeth and muted articulation style affect the expected viseme shapes.
- The complexity of human speech and the variability of visemes are highlighted as significant challenges in creating accurate and natural-looking speech simulations.
</result>

semantic_path: https://melindaozel.com/ARkit to FACS Reference Sheet
browser_content:
## Comprehensive Information about 'ARkit to FACS Reference Sheet'

### Purpose:
The ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet is designed to translate ARKit face shapes into their Facial Action Coding System (FACS) equivalents, clearing up confusion and common misconceptions in the process.

### Key Features:
1. **Quick Table:** A comprehensive table that maps ARKit labels to their corresponding FACS names, muscles, and references.
2. **Detailed Explanations:** The guide provides detailed explanations for each ARKit label, including their FACS equivalents and the muscles involved.
3. **Additional Resources:** Links to additional resources, including a FACS Cheat Sheet and a guide on creating ARKit's 52 facial blendshapes.

### Instructions:
1. The guide is meant to be used by developers and researchers working with ARKit and FACS.
2. Users can scroll down to access the quick table and detailed explanations.

### Links:
1. [FACS Cheat Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/facs-cheat-sheet/)
2. [Comprehensive Guide](https://melindaozel.com/arkit-to-facs-translation-guide/)
3. [The Ultimate Guide to Creating ARKit’s 52 Facial Blendshapes](https://pooyadeperson.com/the-ultimate-guide-to-creating-arkits-52-facial-blendshapes/)

### Other Relevant Details:
1. **Missing FACS Shapes:** The guide notes that ARKit is missing some important FACS shapes, including AU11, AU13, AU23, AU38, and AU39.
2. **Muscular Correlates:** The guide provides information on the muscular correlates for each FACS shape, with notes on oversimplifications.
3. **Author's Expertise:** The author, Melinda Ozel, is a facial motion expert with 13 years of experience in FACS and facial anatomy.

Attachments:

semantic_path: https://melindaozel.com/Visemes Muted Speech
browser_content:
## Visemes Muted Speech Explanation

The webpage discusses the challenges of audio-to-face technology, specifically the variability of visemes in speech. Visemes are the visual representations of phonemes, which are the smallest units of sound in a language. The article explains that the 'right' viseme shape is relative and depends on various factors, including coarticulation, emotions, volume, and speed.

### Relevant Links

* [Viseme Cheat Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-cheat-sheet/): A resource provided by the author for more rigid and clock-like examples of visemes.
* [Wikipedia: Voiced labiodental nasal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced_labiodental_nasal#:~:text=Thelabiodentalpronunciationof,liptouchestheupperteeth.): Explains labiodentalization and its effects on phonemes.
* [Wikipedia: Voiceless labiodental affricate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_labiodental_affricate): Discusses the sound [p̪͡f] and its occurrence in English.

### Instructions

The article does not provide explicit instructions, but it implies that understanding the variability of visemes is crucial for accurate audio-to-face technology. The author suggests embracing the complexity of human behavior and mechanics to improve the accuracy of simulated speech.

### Key Features

* Variability of visemes in speech
* Effects of coarticulation, emotions, volume, and speed on visemes
* Importance of understanding phonemes and their visual representations
* Examples of labiodentalization and its impact on phonemes

### Other Relevant Details

* The author is a facial motion expert specializing in the Facial Action Coding System (FACS) and facial anatomy.
* The article references a specific example from the TV show 'Severance' Season 2, Episode 7, where the character Gemma delivers a line with gritted teeth and muted articulation.
* The author provides a breakdown of the phonemes and visemes in the example sentence, highlighting the challenges of accurately representing speech.
* The article concludes by encouraging readers to accept the complexity of human behavior and mechanics, citing a quote from neuroscientist Robert Sapolsky.

Attachments:

topic: Its All In the Eyes and Other Lies
browser_content:
## Comprehensive Information about "It's All In the Eyes" and Other Lies

### Purpose
The article critiques contemporary emotion research, particularly the reliance on Paul Ekman's work and the Facial Action Coding System (FACS), highlighting the limitations and biases in understanding facial expressions of emotion.

### Relevant Links
- Original post on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/melindaozel_marketing-psychology-facetech-activity-6763123440535789568-XLo_
- Research paper on Duchenne Smile: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/341280748_Reconsidering_the_Duchenne_Smile_Examining_the_Relationships_between_the_Duchenne_Marker_Smile_Intensity_and_Positive_Emotion
- Article on Hard Feelings: https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2015/02/hard-feelings-sciences-struggle-to-define-emotions/385711/
- Article on Artificial Intelligence Misreading Human Emotion: https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2021/04/artificial-intelligence-misreading-human-emotion/618696/

### Instructions
The article does not provide specific instructions but encourages readers to think critically about the complexities of facial expressions and emotions.

### Key Features
1. **Critique of Ekman's Work**: The article challenges the over-reliance on Paul Ekman's theories on facial expressions and emotions, suggesting that his work, while foundational, is dated and subject to bias.
2. **Experiment on Authentic Smiles**: The author conducted an experiment where she posted two photos of herself smiling (one posed and one spontaneous) and asked her audience to guess which was authentic. 85% of the over 170 responses were incorrect.
3. **Complexity of Facial Expressions**: The article discusses the intricacies of facial anatomy and the factors that influence the appearance of facial expressions, including muscle structure, facial fat, and age.
4. **Limitations of Current Emotion Research**: It highlights the shortcomings in current research, particularly the failure to account for diverse facial anatomies and the reliance on static images rather than dynamic video.
5. **Implications for Academia, Tech, and Entertainment**: The article suggests that the current understanding of emotions and facial expressions is insufficient for advancing research, technology, and entertainment, particularly in areas like AI and facial animation.

### Other Relevant Details
- The article emphasizes the need for a more comprehensive approach to understanding emotions, incorporating diverse perspectives and newer research.
- It references several studies and articles that support a more nuanced view of facial expressions and emotions.
- The author's expertise in FACS and facial anatomy is highlighted, along with her work in expression tracking, facial animation, and AI lipsync.

Attachments:

The article "It's All In the Eyes" and Other Lies: A Critique On Contemporary Emotion Research critiques the current understanding of emotion research, particularly focusing on the reliability of facial expressions in determining genuine emotions.

- Original post on LinkedIn: [https://www.linkedin.com/posts/melindaozel_marketing-psychology-facetech-activity-6763123440535789568-XLo_](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/melindaozel_marketing-psychology-facetech-activity-6763123440535789568-XLo_)

semantic_path: https://melindaozel.com//Explore the full course
browser_content:
## FACS Cram Session Information

### Purpose
The FACS Cram Session is designed to provide a comprehensive review of the Facial Action Coding System (FACS) and its application in facial animation and facial technology research.

### Key Features
- 100-120 minutes of lecture time + 20-30 minutes of Q&A
- 380+ slides of visually-focused content (photos, GIFs, videos, custom-made diagrams)
- PDF copies for personal and team use
- Long-term access to live lecture recordings or pre-recorded sessions

### Outline
1. Intro to FACS: Origin & Action Units
2. Upper face Part I: The Eyebrows
3. Upper face Part II: The Eyes
4. Middle Face: The Nose & Nearby
5. Lip Corner Movers: Raising & Lowering Illusions
6. Lower Face: The Mouth & Below
7. The Jaw & Action Descriptors

### Related Links
- [FACS Lectures & Training](https://melindaozel.com/services/lectures-training/)
- [Premium Resources](https://melindaozel.com/premium-resources/)
- [Facial Action Coding System (FACS) – Cheat Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/facs-cheat-sheet/)

### Instructions
To access the FACS Cram Session, choose between two options: Instant-Access, Pre-Recorded FACS Lectures or Live Studio Session.

#### For Instant-Access, Pre-Recorded FACS Lectures:
- Email [facetheFACS@melindaozel.com](mailto:facetheFACS@melindaozel.com) to discuss group options

#### For Live Studio Session:
- Email [facetheFACS@melindaozel.com](mailto:facetheFACS@melindaozel.com) with company name, team specialization, team size, and additional information

### Contact Information
- Email: [facetheFACS@melindaozel.com](mailto:facetheFACS@melindaozel.com)
- Website: [https://melindaozel.com](https://melindaozel.com)

### Other Relevant Resources
- Testimonials from various industry professionals
- Links to Melinda Ozel's social media profiles (Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn)

Attachments:

<result>
## Comprehensive Information about 'FACS Reference Sheet'

### Explanation
The FACS Reference Sheet, also known as the FACS Cheat Sheet, is a visual guide to the Facial Action Coding System (FACS). It provides detailed information on FACS-based action unit (AU) references and the facial muscles they correspond to. The sheet also includes references and descriptions for anatomically-based facial movements not documented in FACS.

### Relevant Links
1. **FACS Lite: Photos (FREE)**: [https://melindaozel.com/facs-lite-still-fast/](https://melindaozel.com/facs-lite-still-fast/)
2. **FACS Study Guide (PAYWALL)**: [https://melindaozel.com/facs-study-guide/](https://melindaozel.com/facs-study-guide/)
3. **Viseme Cheat Sheet (FREE)**: [https://melindaozel.com/viseme-cheat-sheet/](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-cheat-sheet/)
4. **ARKit to FACS Cheat Sheet (FREE)**: [https://melindaozel.com/arkit-to-facs-cheat-sheet/](https://melindaozel.com/arkit-to-facs-cheat-sheet/)

### Instructions
The FACS Cheat Sheet is organized by facial regions, including the forehead, eyes, middle face, lips, and jaw. Each section details specific action units (AUs), their corresponding facial muscles, and the actions they perform. The guide also includes notes on variations, related actions, and distinctions between similar AUs.

### Important Details
1. **Action Units (AUs)**: The sheet lists various AUs, such as AU1 (inner brow raiser), AU6 (cheek raiser), and AU12 (lip corner puller), along with their actions and corresponding muscles.
2. **Non-FACS Movements**: The guide also documents facial movements not included in the original FACS system, marked as "#notFACS," such as "ears up & back" and "open-eyed blink."
3. **Muscle Anatomy**: Detailed information about the facial muscles involved in each AU is provided, along with notes on muscle variability and interactions.
4. **Citations**: The page provides citation information in APA and BibTeX formats for referencing the FACS Cheat Sheet.

### Additional Resources
1. **Premium Resources**: [https://melindaozel.com/premium-resources/](https://melindaozel.com/premium-resources/)
2. **FACS Lectures & Training**: [https://melindaozel.com/services/lectures-training/](https://melindaozel.com/services/lectures-training/)
3. **Other Cheat Sheets**: Links to other related cheat sheets, such as the Viseme Cheat Sheet and ARKit to FACS Cheat Sheet, are provided at the bottom of the page.

### Publication Details
- **Author**: Melinda Ozel
- **Published**: February 20, 2020
- **Updated**: October 30, 2025
</result>

semantic_path: https://melindaozel.com//ARkit to FACS Reference Sheet
browser_content:
## ARKit to FACS Cheat Sheet Content

### Introduction
The webpage provides a detailed guide on translating ARKit face shapes into their Facial Action Coding System (FACS) equivalents. It explains the difficulties in distinguishing similar FACS shapes and the lack of clear explanations in Apple's devkit.

### Quick Table

| ARKit Label | Corresponding FACS Name(s) | Corresponding Muscle(s) | Reference |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| browInnerUp | AU 1 – inner brow raiser | frontalis, medial portion |  |
| browOuter (left & right) | AU2 – outer brow raiser | frontalis, lateral portion |  |
| browDown (left & right) | AU4 – brow lowerer | corrugator supercilii, depressor supercilii, procerus |  |
| eyeWide (left & right) | AU5 – upper lid raiser | levator palpebrae superioris |  |
| cheekSquint (left & right) | AU6 – cheek raiser | orbicularis oculi, orbital portion |  |
| eyeSquint (left & right) | AU7 – lid tightener | orbicularis oculi, palpebral portion |  |
| eyeBlink (left & right) | AU45 – blink | relaxation of levator palpebrae superioris & contraction of the palpebral portion of orbicularis oculi |  |
| eyeLookUp (left & right) | M63 – eyes up | superior rectus & inferior oblique | * |
| eyeLookDown (left & right) | M64 – eyes down | inferior rectus & superior oblique | * |
| eyeLookIn (left & right) | AU66 – crosseye (when applied to both eyes at once) | medial rectus |  |
| eyeLookOut (left & right) | AU65 – walleye (when applied to both eyes at once) | lateral rectus |  |
| noseSneer (left & right) | AU9 – nose wrinkler | levator labii superioris alaeque nasi |  |
| mouthUpper (left & right) | AU10 – upper lip raiser | levator labii superioris |  |
| mouthSmile (left & right) | AU12 – lip corner puller | zygomaticus major |  |
| mouth (left & right) |  |  | See notes in [Comprehensive Guide](https://melindaozel.com/arkit-to-facs-translation-guide/). |
| mouthDimple (left & right) | AU14 – dimpler | buccinator |  |
| mouthFrown (left & right) | AU15 – lip corner depressor | depressor anguli oris |  |
| mouthLowerDown (left & right) | AU16 – lower lip depressor | depressor labii inferioris |  |
| mouthShrugUpper | AU17 – chin raiser – upper split | secondary effect from the mentalis |  |
| mouthShrugLower | AU17 – chin raiser – lower split | mentalis |  |
| cheekPuff | AD34 – puff | buccinator |  |
| mouthPucker | AU18 – lip pucker | incisivus labii superioris, incisivus labii inferioris |  |
| mouthStretch (left & right) | AU20 – lip stretcher | risorius |  |
| mouthFunnel | AU22 – lip funneler | orbicularis oris |  |
| mouthPress (left & right) | AU24 – lip presser | orbicularis oris |  |
| mouthClose | AU8 | orbicularis oris | See notes in [Comprehensive Guide](https://melindaozel.com/arkit-to-facs-translation-guide/). |
| mouthRoll (upper & lower) | AU28 – lips suck | orbicularis oris |  |
| jawOpen | AU26 – jaw drop or AU27 – mouth stretch | (AU26) relaxation of masseter, temporalis, and internal pterygoid muscles or (AU27) lateral pterygoid and the suprahyoid muscles |  |
| jaw (left & right) | AD30 – jaw sideways | pterygoids and temporalis |  |
| jawForward | AD29 – jaw thrust | pterygoids and masseter |  |

### Other Notes
* ARKit is missing some important actions for everyday expression and emotion, including:
    + AU11 – nasolabial furrow deepener – zygomaticus minor
    + AU13 – sharp lip puller – levator anguli oris
    + AU23 – lip tightener – orbicularis oris
    + AU38 – nostril dilator – dilator naris
    + AU39 – nostril compressor – depressor septi & transverse nasalis
* Other missing shapes:
    + vertical lip tightener – orbicularis oris (See FACS Cheat Sheet for more)

### Additional Resources
* [FACS Cheat Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/facs-cheat-sheet/)
* [The Ultimate Guide to Creating ARKit’s 52 Facial Blendshapes](https://pooyadeperson.com/the-ultimate-guide-to-creating-arkits-52-facial-blendshapes/) by Pooya Deperson

### Related Content
* [Animation Tips For Smiles](https://melindaozel.com/animation-tips-for-smiles/)
* [Killer Smiles: A Fine Line Between Creepy and Beautiful](https://melindaozel.com/killer-smiles/)
* [“It’s All In the Eyes” and Other Lies: A Critique On Contemporary Emotion Research](https://melindaozel.com/its-all-in-the-eyes-and-other-lies/)
* [Viseme Variability: Gritted Teeth & Muted Speech](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-variability-gritted-teeth-muted-speech/)
* [Cheek Raiser vs. Lid Tightener](https://melindaozel.com/cheek-raiser-vs-lid-tightener/)
* [ARKit & Other Face Tracking Mistakes](https://melindaozel.com/arkit-other-face-tracking-mistakes/)

The 'ARkit to FACS Reference Sheet' is a comprehensive guide that helps in translating ARKit facial blendshapes into FACS equivalents. It includes a detailed table mapping ARKit labels to their corresponding FACS names and muscles involved. The page also provides additional resources and related content for further understanding.

Attachments:

qa_pairs.question: What is the ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet?
qa_pairs.answer: The ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet is a comprehensive guide that translates ARKit facial blendshapes into their Facial Action Coding System (FACS) equivalents. It includes a detailed table mapping ARKit labels to their corresponding FACS names and muscles involved.

qa_pairs.question: How do I use the ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet?
qa_pairs.answer: To use the ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet, refer to the detailed table provided, which maps ARKit labels to their corresponding FACS names and muscles involved. You can use this information to understand how ARKit facial blendshapes correspond to FACS actions.

qa_pairs.question: Why is the ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet important?
qa_pairs.answer: The ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet is important because it helps developers and researchers understand how ARKit facial blendshapes correspond to FACS actions, which is crucial for creating realistic facial expressions in various applications, including animation and emotion research.

qa_pairs.question: When should I use the ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet?
qa_pairs.answer: You should use the ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet whenever you need to translate ARKit facial blendshapes into FACS equivalents, such as when working on projects involving facial expression analysis or animation.

qa_pairs.question: Where can I find the ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet?
qa_pairs.answer: The ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet is available on the webpage that provides the detailed guide. You can also find related content and additional resources on the same website, including links to other relevant articles and guides.

qa_pairs.question: Who should use the ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet?
qa_pairs.answer: Developers, researchers, and animators working on projects involving facial expression analysis, animation, or emotion research should use the ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet to ensure accurate translation of ARKit facial blendshapes into FACS equivalents.

qa_pairs.question: What are some limitations of ARKit according to the reference sheet?
qa_pairs.answer: According to the reference sheet, ARKit is missing some important actions for everyday expression and emotion, including AU11, AU13, AU23, AU38, and AU39. It also lacks certain shapes like the vertical lip tightener.

qa_pairs.question: How does the ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet help with understanding facial expressions?
qa_pairs.answer: The ARKit to FACS Reference Sheet helps with understanding facial expressions by providing a detailed mapping of ARKit facial blendshapes to FACS actions, which enables more accurate analysis and creation of facial expressions.

qa_pairs.question: What additional resources are available for understanding FACS and ARKit?
qa_pairs.answer: Additional resources available include the FACS Cheat Sheet (https://melindaozel.com/facs-cheat-sheet/), 'The Ultimate Guide to Creating ARKit’s 52 Facial Blendshapes' by Pooya Deperson (https://pooyadeperson.com/the-ultimate-guide-to-creating-arkits-52-facial-blendshapes/), and several related articles on facial expressions and animation.

## Quick Tips on How to Optimize Your Protocol

The webpage provides comprehensive information on optimizing facial capture protocols. The key points are summarized below:

### Key Features and Instructions

1. **Be use case-minded**: Design the protocol according to its purpose. For example, if the goal is to capture data for a product aimed at co-working, prioritize prosocial, collaborative, and everyday expressions.
2. **Design for logical flow**: Group similar expressions together (e.g., brow-based poses, eye-based poses) and progress from easy to difficult within each section.
3. **Ensure example imagery and descriptions match the target pose**: Review example poses rigorously to avoid conflicting instructions.

### Relevant Links

* [Free & Downloadable Vintage Facial Anatomy Books](https://melindaozel.com/free-downloadable-facial-anatomy-books/)

## Comprehensive Information about 'Visemes Muted Speech'

### Explanation
The article discusses the challenges of accurately representing speech through visemes, particularly when dealing with gritted teeth and muted articulation. Visemes are visual representations of speech sounds, and their accuracy is crucial for effective lipsync technologies.

### Purpose
The purpose of the article is to highlight the complexities and variations in speech articulation, emphasizing that the 'right' viseme shape is relative and dependent on various factors beyond coarticulation.

### Relevant Links
- [Viseme Cheat Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-cheat-sheet/): A resource for understanding visemes.
- [LinkedIn Profile of Melinda Ozel](http://linkedin.com/in/melindaozel): Information about the author's background in facial motion expertise and AI lipsync technologies.
- [Wikipedia on Labiodentalization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_labiodental_affricate) and [Voiced Labiodental Nasal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced_labiodental_nasal#:~:text=Thelabiodentalpronunciationof,liptouchestheupperteeth.): Explaining labiodentalization and its impact on speech sounds.
- [Robert Sapolsky's Wikipedia Page](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Sapolsky): Information about the neuroscientist and primatologist quoted in the article.

### Instructions
The article does not provide direct instructions but discusses the importance of understanding and embracing the complexities of human speech and articulation for those working in facial animation and audio-to-face technologies.

### Phone Numbers
No phone numbers are mentioned in the article.

### People Names
- **Melinda Ozel**: The author of the article, a facial motion expert.
- **Dichen Lachman**: The actress who played Gemma in _Severance_.
- **Robert Sapolsky**: A neuroscientist and primatologist quoted in the article.

### Addresses
No physical addresses are provided in the article.

### Key Features
- **Viseme Variability**: The article discusses how visemes change with different articulation styles, such as gritted teeth and muted speech.
- **Phonemes and Visemes**: The relationship between phonemes (units of sound) and visemes (visual representations of these sounds) is explored, highlighting that even reliable visemes like /p/, /b/, and /m/ can vary.
- **Anchor Points in Speech**: The article identifies /p/, /b/, and /m/ as typically reliable visemes but notes that even these can be subject to variation, such as labiodentalization.

### Other Relevant Details
- The article references a specific scene from _Severance_ Season 2, Episode 7, where the character Gemma speaks through gritted teeth, illustrating the challenge of viseme accuracy in such cases.
- It mentions the concept of allophones, which are variations of phonemes that do not change the meaning of a word.
- The author emphasizes the importance of accepting and understanding the variability and complexity of human speech for advancements in lipsync technologies and facial animation.

Attachments:

qa_pairs.question: How do visemes change with different articulation styles?
qa_pairs.answer: Visemes change significantly with different articulation styles. ## Detailed Information on 'Reality of Viseme Variability in Speech Production'

### Explanation
The webpage discusses the complexity of viseme variability in speech production, particularly in the context of audio-to-face technologies and facial animation. Visemes are the visual equivalents of phonemes, which are the smallest units of sound in speech. The article highlights that there is no single mouth shape that defines a particular speech sound due to the variability in articulation with every phoneme, syllable, and word.

### Key Features
1. **Viseme Variability**: The article emphasizes that the 'right' mouth shape for a viseme is relative and depends on various conditions beyond coarticulation.
2. **Gritted Teeth and Muted Speech**: An example from the TV series 'Severance' is used to illustrate how gritted teeth and muted articulation affect viseme formation.
3. **Phonemes and Visemes**: The article provides a detailed analysis of phonemes and their corresponding visemes, noting that even the most contrastive lip shapes can be indiscernible.
4. **Anchor Points**: The phonemes /p/, /b/, and /m/ are discussed as potentially reliable anchor points for assessing the quality of simulated speech due to their typically closed lip shape.

### Relevant Links
- [Viseme Cheat Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-cheat-sheet/): A resource provided by the author for more rigid examples of visemes.
- [LinkedIn Profile of Melinda Ozel](http://linkedin.com/in/melindaozel): The author's professional profile.

- [Wikipedia on Voiced Labiodental Nasal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced_labiodental_nasal#:~:text=Thelabiodentalpronunciationof,liptouchestheupperteeth.): Discusses the labiodental pronunciation of nasals.

### Instructions
The article does not provide direct instructions but suggests that understanding and embracing the variability and complexity of human speech and behavior is crucial for advancing in fields like facial animation and audio-to-face research.

### People Names
1. **Melinda Ozel**: The author of the article, a facial motion expert specializing in the Facial Action Coding System (FACS) and facial anatomy.

The webpage discusses the complexity of viseme variability in speech production, particularly in the context of audio-to-face technologies and facial animation. Visemes are the visual equivalents of phonemes, which are the smallest units of sound in speech. The article highlights that there is no single mouth shape that defines a particular speech sound due to the variability in articulation with every phoneme, syllable, and word.

### Key Features
1. **Viseme Variability**: The article emphasizes that the "right" mouth shape for a viseme is relative and depends on various conditions beyond coarticulation.
2. **Gritted Teeth and Muted Speech**: An example from the TV series "Severance" is used to illustrate how gritted teeth and muted articulation affect viseme formation.
3. **Phonemes and Visemes**: The article provides a detailed analysis of phonemes and their corresponding visemes, noting that even the most contrastive lip shapes can be indiscernible.
4. **Anchor Points**: The phonemes /p/, /b/, and /m/ are discussed as potentially reliable anchor points for assessing the quality of simulated speech due to their typically closed lip shape.

topic: Are Duchenne smiles as reliable as once thought
browser_content:
## Comprehensive Information about 'Are Duchenne Smiles as Reliable as Once Thought'

### Explanation
The article critiques contemporary emotion research, focusing on the reliability of Duchenne smiles as indicators of genuine emotion. It discusses how the presence of the Duchenne marker (orbicularis oculi contraction) is not a definitive indicator of a genuine smile, citing recent studies that show its presence in both felt and unfelt smiles.

### Relevant Links
1. [Reconsidering the Duchenne Smile: Examining the Relationships between the Duchenne Marker, Smile Intensity, and Positive Emotion](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/341280748_Reconsidering_the_Duchenne_Smile_Examining_the_Relationships_between_the_Duchenne_Marker_Smile_Intensity_and_Positive_Emotion)
2. [Why Faces Don’t Always Tell the Truth About Feelings](https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-00507-5)
3. [Hard Feelings: Science’s Struggle to Define Emotions](https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2015/02/hard-feelings-sciences-struggle-to-define-emotions/385711/)
4. [Artificial Intelligence Is Misreading Human Emotion](https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2021/04/artificial-intelligence-misreading-human-emotion/618696/)

### Instructions
The article suggests that researchers and practitioners should adopt a more comprehensive approach to understanding emotions and facial expressions, integrating multiple theories and critiques.

### People Names
1. Melinda Ozel (author of the article)
2. Paul Ekman (psychologist and developer of the Facial Action Coding System)
3. Charles Darwin (early contributor to the study of facial expressions and emotions)

### Key Features
1. **Duchenne Smile**: A smile characterized by the contraction of both the zygomaticus major muscle and the orbicularis oculi muscle.
2. **Felt vs. Unfelt Smiles**: The distinction between spontaneous, genuine smiles and posed, artificial smiles.
3. **Facial Anatomy**: The study of the muscles and structure of the face, crucial for understanding facial expressions.

### Other Relevant Details
1. The article challenges the long-held assumption that Duchenne smiles are reliable indicators of genuine positive emotion, citing studies that show the complexity of interpreting facial expressions.
2. It highlights the limitations and biases in current emotion research, particularly the over-reliance on the work of Paul Ekman and the lack of diversity in study participants.
3. The author, Melinda Ozel, is a facial motion expert with experience in Facial Action Coding System (FACS) and facial anatomy, having worked on projects such as expression tracking and AI lipsync.

Attachments:

However, there are several resources related to Facial Action Coding System (FACS) mentioned:

## Key Features and Capabilities of FACS Resources:
1. **FACS Study Guide**: Isolated FACS references as GIFs moving from neutral to pose, photos, and detailed descriptions.
2. **Eyebrow Combos**: Visuals of brow action combinations with descriptions and multiple angle GIFs.
3. **Upper Face: Expanded**: Upper face action units (brows and orbital muscles) and their common combinations. Described in detail and shown with multiple angles.
4. **Lower Face: Expanded**: Lower face action units and their common combinations. Described in detail and shown with multiple angles.
5. **Emotion References**: Authentic emotion references documented from real moments with contextual descriptions.
6. **FACS Video References**: A select set of FACS expression and video references and some draw-overs. Especially helpful for those studying brow lowering.

## Links:
1. [FACS Study Guide](https://melindaozel.com/facs-study-guide/)
2. [Eyebrow Combos](https://melindaozel.com/facs-cheat-sheet/eyebrow-combos-cheat-sheet/)
3. [Upper Face: Expanded](https://melindaozel.com/upper-face-expanded/)
4. [Lower Face: Expanded](https://melindaozel.com/lower-face-cheat-sheet/)
5. [Emotion References](https://melindaozel.com/emotion-references/)
6. [FACS Video References](https://melindaozel.com/facs-video-references/)

## People Names:
1. **Melinda Ozel**: Facial motion expert specializing in the Facial Action Coding System (FACS) and facial anatomy.

## Related Resources:
1. **ARKit to FACS: Full Guide**: Expanded version of the ARKit to FACS Cheat Sheet, explaining how things work and how to use each shape.
2. **Viseme Cheat Sheet**: Viseme & speech reference guide with videos shown in 1x speed and slow motion.

## Contact Information:
1. **LinkedIn Profile**: [Melinda Ozel's LinkedIn](https://linkedin.com/in/melindaozel)
2. **Twitter Profile**: [Melinda Ozel's Twitter](https://x.com/melindaozel)
3. **Instagram Profile**: [Melinda Ozel's Instagram](https://instagram.com/manicexpression)

## Other Information:
1. **Copyright**: Copyright © 2020-2025 **Melinda Ozel**. All rights reserved.
2. **Terms & Conditions**: [Terms & Conditions](https://melindaozel.com/terms-conditions/)
</result>

semantic_path: https://melindaozel.com//EXPLORE MORE PREMIUM
browser_content:
## Detailed Information about 'EXPLORE MORE PREMIUM'

The webpage does not directly mention 'EXPLORE MORE PREMIUM'. However, it provides detailed information about 'Premium Resources', which seems to be related.

### Premium Face Resources By Topic

The premium resources are categorized into three main topics:
1. Facial Action Coding System (FACS) & Facial Anatomy
2. Face Tracking & Lipsync Technology
3. Mixed Posts: From FACS to Wrinkles & Eye Blinks

### Facial Action Coding System (FACS) & Facial Anatomy

The following resources are available under this category:
* **FACS Study Guide**: Isolated FACS references as GIFs moving from neutral to pose, photos, and detailed descriptions. [Link](https://melindaozel.com/facs-study-guide/)
* **Eyebrow Combos**: Visuals of brow action combinations with descriptions and multiple angle GIFs. [Link](https://melindaozel.com/facs-cheat-sheet/eyebrow-combos-cheat-sheet/)
* **Upper Face: Expanded**: Upper face action units (brows and orbital muscles) and their common combinations. Described in detail and shown with multiple angles. [Link](https://melindaozel.com/upper-face-expanded/)
* **Lower Face: Expanded**: Lower face action units and their common combinations. Described in detail and shown with multiple angles. [Link](https://melindaozel.com/lower-face-cheat-sheet/)
* **Emotion References**: Authentic emotion references documented from real moments with contextual descriptions. [Link](https://melindaozel.com/emotion-references/)
* **FACS Video References**: A select set of FACS expression and video references and some draw-overs. Especially helpful for those studying brow lowering. [Link](https://melindaozel.com/facs-video-references/)

### Face Tracking & Lipsync Technology

The following resources are available under this category:
* **Posed Expression Captures**: A series of tips for how to get started + a detailed guide for handling upper face expression captures. [Link](https://melindaozel.com/posed-expression-capture-guide/)
* **ARKit to FACS: Full Guide**: The expanded version of the ARKit to FACS Cheat Sheet. Explains how things work and how you might want to use each shape. [Link](https://melindaozel.com/arkit-to-facs-translation-guide/)
* **Viseme Cheat Sheet**: Viseme & speech reference guide with videos shown in 1x speed and slow motion. [Link](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/)

### Mixed Posts: From FACS to Wrinkles & Eye Blinks

This category includes advanced facial expression tips, research, instructional guides, and commentary. Some of the available resources are:
* **Upper Lip Raiser vs. Nasolabial Furrow Deepener**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/upper-lip-raiser-vs-nasolabial-furrow-deepener/)
* **Stylized Facial Expression Design**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/stylized-facial-expression-design/)
* **Forehead Dynamics – Frontalis vs. Occipitalis**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/forehead-dynamics-frontalis-vs-occipitalis/)
* **Lip Tightener vs. Lip Presser**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/lip-tightener-vs-lip-presser/)
* **Eyebrow Shapes and Character Design**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/eyebrow-shapes-and-character-design/)
* **Advanced Blend Shape Tips For Blinks**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/advanced-blend-shape-tips-for-blinks/)
* **Hot Tips For Animating Blinks**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/hot-tips-for-animating-blinks/)
* **All About Upper Lid Raiser – AU5**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/all-about-upper-lid-raiser-au5/)
* **Nasolabial Furrow Deepener vs. Upper Lip Raiser**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/levator-labii-superioris-vs-zygomaticus-minor/)
* **Colors of Sadness**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/colors-of-sadness/)
* **Leveraging Facial Muscle Variation**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/leveraging-facial-muscle-variation/)
* **Zygomaticus Major Variations & the Dimple**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/zygomaticus-major-variations-the-dimple/)
* **Frontalis Variation: Why Wrinkle Patterns Differ**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/frontalis-variation/)
* **Inner Brow Raiser: Deep Dive**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/inner-brow-raiser-deep-dive/)
* **Wrinkle Tips For Character Artists, Part II: Static Forms**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/a-wrinkle-in-time-part-ii/)
* **A Wrinkle In Time, Part I: How to Build Characters With Real Story Lines**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/a-wrinkle-in-time-building-characters-with-real-story-lines/)
* **Building Smiles – The Right Way**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/building-smiles-the-right-way/)
* **Bypassing VR Headset Occlusion in Face Tracking**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/bypassing-vr-headset-occlusion-in-face-tracking/)
* **Breaking Down Nose Wrinkler (AU9)**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/breaking-down-nose-wrinkler/)
* **Lip Tightener (AU23) and Why Everyone Gets It Wrong**: [Link](https://melindaozel.com/lip-tightener/)

To access these premium resources, users can visit the [Premium Resources page](https://melindaozel.com/premium-resources/).

To access the premium content, users need to have a membership. The membership options are available on the [Become A Member page](https://melindaozel.com/subscription-options/), with plans starting at $24 Monthly and $112 Yearly.

There are no explicit instructions on how to access the premium content. However, it is likely that users need to log in to their accounts to access the resources. The login link is available on the top navigation menu. [Login](https://melindaozel.com/login/)

Attachments:

### Overview
Melinda Ozel is a consultant and educator specializing in facial expressions, FACS (Facial Action Coding System), and facial anatomy. Her background originated in academia, migrated to tech, and now exists between art, science, and technology.

### Key Details
- **Expertise**: Facial expressions, FACS, facial anatomy
- **Industries**: Film, game, tech, etc.
- **Products/Media**: Emoji, AR/VR face tracking, AAA game characters, photoreal animals, AI, deepfake technologies
- **Experience**: 13 years in expression tracking, facial animation, and AI lipsync

### Relevant Projects & Patents
1. **VR & Face Tracking Tech**
   - Meta Quest Pro: Expression Researcher & Expression Data Specialist
   - Patents: 
     - System and method for applying an expression to an avatar (patent 10970907) – Co-inventor
     - Systems and methods for improving animation of computer-generated avatars (patents 11270487, 11468616) – Co-inventor

## Comprehensive Information about the Privacy Policy

### Purpose
The purpose of the privacy policy is to inform users about how the website https://melindaozel.com collects, uses, and protects their personal data.

### Relevant Links
- https://melindaozel.com (website address)
- https://automattic.com/privacy/ (Gravatar service privacy policy)

### Instructions
- To avoid uploading images with embedded location data, users should check their images for EXIF GPS data before uploading.
- Users can request to receive an exported file of their personal data or request erasure of their personal data by contacting the website administrators.

### Phone Numbers
- No phone numbers are mentioned in the privacy policy.

### People Names
- Melinda Ozel (website owner)

### Addresses
- No physical addresses are mentioned in the privacy policy. The website URL is https://melindaozel.com.

### Other Important Details
1. **Comments**: The website collects data shown in the comments form, IP address, and browser user agent string to help spam detection. An anonymized string created from the user's email address may be provided to the Gravatar service.
2. **Media**: Users should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS).
3. **Cookies**: The website uses cookies to save user convenience, login information, and screen display choices. Cookies last for varying durations, from a few days to a year.
4. **Embedded Content**: Embedded content from other websites may collect data about users, use cookies, and track user interaction.
5. **Data Sharing**: If a user requests a password reset, their IP address will be included in the reset email.
6. **Data Retention**: Comments and metadata are retained indefinitely. User profile information is stored until the user edits or deletes it.
7. **User Rights**: Users can request an exported file of their personal data or request erasure of their personal data.
8. **Data Sending**: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

### Additional Information
The privacy policy is available in multiple languages, accessible through links at the bottom of the webpage.

Attachments:

semantic_path: https://melindaozel.com/Viseme Cheat Sheet/Viseme Cheat Sheet
browser_content:
## Viseme Cheat Sheet

### Definition and Purpose
The Viseme Cheat Sheet is a visual guide for artists and researchers working on facial animation or speech studies. It lists American English phonemes and the visemes they commonly map to.

### What is a Viseme?
A viseme is a group of phonemes that are visually indistinct from one another. For example, the phonemes /f/ and /v/ are acoustically distinct but visually indistinguishable.

### Interactive Phoneme to Viseme Chart
The webpage includes an interactive chart for English consonants, categorized by:
- Bilabial
- Labiodental
- Dental
- Alveolar
- Postalveolar
- Palatal
- Velar
- Glottal

### Viseme Groups and Phonemes
#### Consonants
1. **neutral / silent**: no sound, relaxed
2. **m/b/p viseme group**: 
   - /m/ as in "masseter"
   - /b/ as in "buccinator"
   - /p/ as in "pout"
3. **ʧ / ʤ / ʃ / ʒ viseme group**:
   - /ʧ/ as in "chin"
   - /ʤ/ as in "jaw"
   - /ʃ/ as in "shine"
   - /ʒ/ as in "genre"
4. **d / t viseme group**:
   - /d/ as in "depressor"
   - /t/ as in "temporalis"
5. **f / v viseme group**:
   - /f/ as in "face"
   - /v/ as in "viseme"
6. **g / k viseme group**:
   - /g/ as in "guess"
   - /k/ as in "king"
7. **h phoneme**: as in "hippocampus"
8. **l phoneme**: as in "labial"
9. **n phoneme**: as in "nasal"
10. **r phoneme**: as in "red"
11. **s / z viseme group**:
    - /s/ as in "see"
    - /z/ as in "zygomatic"
12. **θ / ð (th) viseme group**:
    - /θ/ as in "wreath"
    - /ð/ as in "thoracic"

#### Vowels
1. **ɑ (ah) phoneme**: as in "jaw"
2. **æ phoneme**: as in "cat"
3. **ɛ (eh) phoneme**: as in "any"
4. **i (ee) phoneme**: as in "eel"
5. **ɪ (ih) phoneme**: as in "lip"
6. **u (oo) phoneme**: as in "food"
7. **ʊ (ouh) phoneme**: as in "puller"
8. **oʊ (oh) phoneme**: as in "lower"
9. **ɔɪ (oy) phoneme**: as in "joy"
10. **ə (uh) phoneme**: as in "upper"

### Key Terms
- **Alveolar**: Tip of tongue touches the gum line behind the teeth.
- **Bilabial**: Upper and lower lips come together.
- **Labiodental**: Lip touches the teeth.
- **Dental**: Tongue interacts with teeth.
- **Post-alveolar**: Tongue is placed right behind the gum line.
- **Palatal**: Tongue is raised against the center of the mouth roof.
- **Velar**: Back of tongue touches or is held close to the velum (soft palate).
- **Glottal**: Air sound is produced by stopping flow to the glottis.

### Relevant Links
- [Visemes & Articulation Variation](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-variability-gritted-teeth-muted-speech/)
- [Visemes & Asymmetry](https://melindaozel.com/m-b-p-bilabial-visemes/)
- [Full Viseme Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/)

### Further Resources
The page provides links to further resources on visemes, including discussions on viseme variability and asymmetry, and a full viseme guide for more detailed study.

Attachments:

## Viseme Cheat Sheet

### Definition and Pronunciation
- A viseme is a group of phonemes that are visually indistinct from one another.
- The term "viseme" is a portmanteau of "visual" and "phoneme," coined by Cletus G. Fisher in his 1968 paper.
- Pronunciation of "viseme" varies, with common pronunciations including "veye-zeem," "vih-zeem," "veye-seem," and "vih-seem."

### Interactive Phoneme to Viseme Chart
- The page includes an interactive chart for English consonants, categorizing phonemes into viseme groups based on their articulation.
- Categories include Bilabial, Labiodental, Dental, Alveolar, Postalveolar, Palatal, Velar, and Glottal.

### Viseme Groups and Phonemes
#### Consonants
1. **Neutral/Silent**: No sound, relaxed.
2. **m/b/p Viseme Group**: Includes phonemes /m/, /b/, and /p/, all involving bilabial closure.
   - /m/ as in "masseter"
   - /b/ as in "buccinator"
   - /p/ as in "pout"
3. **ʧ / ʤ / ʃ / ʒ Viseme Group**: Post-alveolar affricates and fricatives.
   - /ʧ/ as in "chin"
   - /ʤ/ as in "jaw"
   - /ʃ/ as in "shine"
   - /ʒ/ as in "genre"
4. **d / t Viseme Group**: Alveolar plosives.
   - /d/ as in "depressor"
   - /t/ as in "temporalis"
5. **f / v Viseme Group**: Labiodental fricatives.
   - /f/ as in "face"
   - /v/ as in "viseme"
6. **g / k Viseme Group**: Velar plosives.
   - /g/ as in "guess"
   - /k/ as in "king"
7. **h Phoneme**: Glottal fricative.
   - /h/ as in "hippocampus"
8. **l Phoneme**: Alveolar lateral approximant.
   - /l/ as in "labial"
9. **n Phoneme**: Alveolar nasal.
   - /n/ as in "nasal"
10. **r Phoneme**: Post-alveolar approximant.
    - /r/ as in "red"
11. **s / z Viseme Group**: Alveolar fricatives.
    - /s/ as in "see"
    - /z/ as in "zygomatic"
12. **θ / ð (th) Viseme Group**: Dental fricatives.
    - /θ/ as in "wreath"
    - /ð/ as in "thoracic"

#### Vowels
1. **ɑ (ah) Phoneme**: As in "jaw," "cause."
2. **æ Phoneme**: As in "cat," "FACS."
3. **ɛ (eh) Phoneme**: As in "any," "kept."
4. **i (ee) Phoneme**: As in "eel," "cheese."
5. **ɪ (ih) Phoneme**: As in "lip," "which."
6. **u (oo) Phoneme**: As in "food," "rue."
7. **ʊ (ouh) Phoneme**: As in "puller," "look."
8. **oʊ (oh) Phoneme**: As in "lowerer," "slow."
9. **ɔɪ (oy) Phoneme**: As in "joy," "soy."
10. **ə (uh) Phoneme**: As in "upper," "other."

### Key Terms
- Definitions for terms like "alveolar," "bilabial," "labiodental," "dental," "post-alveolar," "palatal," "velar," and "glottal" are provided to explain the places of articulation.

### Further Reading and Resources
- Links to further resources on visemes, including discussions on viseme variability and asymmetry, are provided.
- A full viseme guide is available for more detailed study.
</result>

- **Dental**: Tongue interacts with teeth.
- **Post-alveolar**: Tongue is placed right behind the gum line.
- **Palatal**: Tongue is raised against the center of the mouth roof.
- **Velar**: Back of tongue touches or is held close to the velum (soft palate).
- **Glottal**: Air sound is produced by stopping flow to the glottis.

### Further Reading
- [Visemes & Articulation Variation](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-variability-gritted-teeth-muted-speech/)
- [Visemes & Asymmetry](https://melindaozel.com/m-b-p-bilabial-visemes/)
- [Full Viseme Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/)
</result>

## Detailed Information about 'Interactive Phoneme to Viseme Chart'

The webpage contains a detailed guide on visemes, including an interactive phoneme to viseme chart for English consonants.

### Key Features of the Chart

1. **View on Desktop**: The interactive chart is best viewed on a desktop.
2. **Phoneme to Viseme Mapping**: The chart maps phonemes to their corresponding visemes.
3. **Categories**: Phonemes are categorized into different groups based on their place of articulation, such as:
   - Bilabial
   - Labiodental
   - Dental
   - Alveolar
   - Postalveolar
   - Palatal
   - Velar
   - Glottal

### Viseme Groups and Phonemes

The webpage lists various viseme groups along with the phonemes they represent:

1. **m/b/p viseme group**: Includes phonemes /m/, /b/, and /p/.
2. **ʧ / ʤ / ʃ / ʒ viseme group**: Includes phonemes /ʧ/, /ʤ/, /ʃ/, and /ʒ/.
3. **d / t viseme group**: Includes phonemes /d/ and /t/.
4. **f / v viseme group**: Includes phonemes /f/ and /v/.
5. **g / k viseme group**: Includes phonemes /g/ and /k/.
6. **s / z viseme group**: Includes phonemes /s/ and /z/.
7. **θ / ð (th) viseme group**: Includes phonemes /θ/ and /ð/.

### Individual Phonemes and Visemes

The webpage also provides detailed information on individual phonemes, including their:
- Phonetic description
- Example words
- Viseme references (images or descriptions)

Some examples include:
- /h/ as in 'h'ippocampus
- /l/ as in 'l'abial
- /n/ as in 'n'asal
- /r/ as in 'r'ed
- Vowels like /ɑ/, /æ/, /ɛ/, /i/, /ɪ/, /u/, /ʊ/, /oʊ/, /ɔɪ/, and /ə/

### Additional Resources

1. **Viseme & Speech Reference Guide**: A more detailed guide available for purchase.
2. **International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) chart**: A link to the Cambridge University IPA chart for listening to phoneme sounds.
3. **Key Terms**: Definitions for terms like alveolar, bilabial, labiodental, etc.

### How to Cite the Page

The webpage provides citation information in APA and BibTeX formats.

### Further Reading

Links to additional resources on viseme variability, asymmetry, and a full viseme guide are available at the bottom of the page.

topic: Interactive Phoneme to Viseme Chart (English Consonants)
browser_content:
## Detailed Information on Interactive Phoneme to Viseme Chart (English Consonants)

### Explanation and Purpose
The 'Interactive Phoneme to Viseme Chart (English Consonants)' is a visual guide for artists and researchers working on facial animation or speech studies. It lists American English phonemes and the visemes they commonly map to. The chart is interactive, allowing users to hover over target phonemes to view their corresponding viseme poses.

### Viseme Groups and Phonemes
1. **m/b/p viseme group**
   - m: bilabial, nasal, voiced
   - b: bilabial, plosive, voiced
   - p: bilabial, plosive, voiceless

2. **ʧ / ʤ / ʃ / ʒ viseme group**
   - ʧ: post-alveolar, affricate, voiceless
   - ʤ: post-alveolar, affricate, voiced
   - ʃ: post-alveolar, fricative, voiceless
   - ʒ: post-alveolar, fricative, voiced

3. **d / t viseme group**
   - d: alveolar, plosive, voiced
   - t: alveolar, plosive, voiceless

4. **f / v viseme group**
   - f: labiodental, fricative, voiceless
   - v: labiodental, fricative, voiced

5. **g / k viseme group**
   - g: velar, plosive, voiced
   - k: velar, plosive, voiceless

6. **s / z viseme group**
   - s: alveolar, fricative, voiceless
   - z: alveolar, fricative, voiced

7. **θ / ð (th) viseme group**
   - θ: dental, fricative, voiceless
   - ð: dental, fricative, voiced

### Individual Phonemes
1. **h phoneme**: glottal, fricative, voiceless
2. **l phoneme**: alveolar, lateral, voiced
3. **n phoneme**: alveolar, nasal, voiced
4. **r phoneme**: post-alveolar, approximant, voiced

### Key Terms
- **alveolar**: tip of tongue touches the gum line behind the teeth
- **bilabial**: upper and lower lips come together
- **labiodental**: lip touches the teeth
- **dental**: tongue interacts with teeth
- **post-alveolar**: tongue is placed right behind the gum line behind teeth
- **palatal**: tongue is raised against the center of mouth roof
- **velar**: back of tongue touches or is held close to the velum (soft palate)
- **glottal**: air sound is produced by stopping flow to glottis
- **labiovelar approximant**: lips and velum both constrict – but not completely

### Instructions
To experience the interactive chart, hover over target phonemes to view their corresponding viseme poses.

### Relevant Links
- [Viseme & Speech Reference Guide](link): A paywalled resource with more detailed descriptions and slow-motion videos.
- [International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) chart](https://example.com/IPA-chart): Hosted on Cambridge University & Press Assessment to hear what each phoneme sounds like.

### Key Features and Capabilities
- Interactive chart for visualizing phoneme to viseme mapping.
- Categorization under different places of articulation such as Bilabial, Labiodental, Dental, Alveolar, Postalveolar, Palatal, Velar, and Glottal.

### Other Relevant Information
The webpage is authored by Melinda Ozel, a facial motion expert specializing in the Facial Action Coding System (FACS) and facial anatomy. The chart is part of a larger resource for artists and researchers in facial animation and speech studies.

Attachments:

## Viseme Information

### What is a Viseme?
A viseme is a group of phonemes that are visually indistinct from one another. It is a portmanteau of 'visual' and 'phoneme,' coined by Cletus G. Fisher in his 1968 paper 'Confusions among visually perceived consonants.'

### Purpose
The purpose of visemes is to help artists and researchers working on facial animation or speech studies by providing a visual guide to American English phonemes and their corresponding visemes.

### Relevant Links
- [Viseme & Speech Reference Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/): A more detailed guide with slow-motion videos (paywalled).

## Viseme Information 

### What is a Viseme?
A viseme is a group of phonemes that are visually indistinct from one another. It is a portmanteau of "visual" and "phoneme," coined by Cletus G. Fisher in his 1968 paper "Confusions among visually perceived consonants."

### Purpose
The purpose of visemes is to help artists and researchers working on facial animation or speech studies by providing a visual guide to American English phonemes and their corresponding visemes.

### Relevant Links
- [Viseme & Speech Reference Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/): A more detailed guide with slow-motion videos (paywalled).
- [International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) chart hosted on Cambridge University & Press Assessment](https://www.cambridge.org/features/IPAchart/): To hear what each phoneme sounds like.
- [Visemes & Articulation Variation](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-variability-gritted-teeth-muted-speech/): Further reading on viseme variability.
- [Visemes & Asymmetry](https://melindaozel.com/m-b-p-bilabial-visemes/): Further reading on viseme asymmetry.

### Instructions
To use the viseme cheat sheet, hover over target phonemes to view their corresponding viseme poses. For more information on each phoneme and viseme, scroll down the page.

### Key Features
- Lists American English phonemes and their corresponding visemes.
- Interactive Phoneme to Viseme Chart for English Consonants.
- Detailed descriptions of various phonemes and their corresponding visemes, including:
  - Bilabial (m/b/p)
  - Labiodental (f/v)
  - Alveolar (d/t, s/z, n, l)
  - Postalveolar (ʧ/ʤ, ʃ/ʒ)
  - Velar (g/k)
  - Glottal (h)
  - Vowels (ɑ, æ, ɛ, i, ɪ, u, ʊ, oʊ, ɔɪ, ə)

### Other Relevant Information
- There is no standardized set of visemes or method for grouping phonemes; it depends on the use case.
- Visemes can vary depending on individual facial features, coarticulation, emotional context, volume, and other speech-related conditions.
- The pronunciation of "viseme" is not standardized, with variations including "veye-zeem," "vih-zeem," etc.

### Additional Resources
- [Viseme Cheat Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-cheat-sheet/): The original page with interactive charts and detailed information.
- Consulting services are available for tailored help with phoneme-to-viseme mapping.
</result>

browser_content:
## Comprehensive Information on 'How are Phonemes Mapped to Visemes'

### Explanation
The webpage at https://melindaozel.com/viseme-cheat-sheet provides a detailed guide on how phonemes are mapped to visemes. A viseme is a group of phonemes that share the same visually observable articulation. The mapping is based on the visual indistinguishability of phonemes during speech.

### Key Mappings
1. /m/, /b/, /p/ are grouped into the same viseme (lips closed or nearly closed)
2. /f/ and /v/ are mapped to the same viseme
3. /t/ and /d/ are grouped into the same viseme
4. /k/ and /g/ are grouped into the same viseme
5. /s/ and /z/ are grouped into the same viseme
6. /θ/ and /ð/ are grouped into the same viseme
7. /ʧ/, /ʤ/, /ʃ/, /ʒ/ are grouped into the same viseme

### Individual Phonemes
The following phonemes are not grouped with others: /h/, /l/, /n/, /r/, /ɑ/, /æ/, /ɛ/, /i/, /ɪ/, /u/, /ʊ/, /oʊ/, /ɔɪ/, /ə/.

### References and Resources
1. Interactive Phoneme to Viseme Chart
2. Viseme & Speech Reference Guide (more comprehensive guide)
3. International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) chart hosted on Cambridge University & Press Assessment

### Citation Information
APA: Ozel, M. (2022, January). Viseme Cheat Sheet. Face the FACS.
BibTeX: @misc{ozel2022viseme, author = {Ozel, Melinda}, title = {Viseme Cheat Sheet}, year = {2022}, month = jan, howpublished = {\url{https://melindaozel.com/viseme-cheat-sheet/}} }

### Important Details
- There is no standardized set of visemes or method for grouping phonemes into visemes.
- The appropriate grouping depends on the specific use case, such as the level of nuance required for facial animation or speech studies.

This information provides a comprehensive understanding of how phonemes are mapped to visemes and the resources available for further study.

Attachments:

## Consonants

### Explanation of Consonants and their Purpose
Consonants are speech sounds made by obstructing airflow with the tongue, teeth, or lips. The Viseme Cheat Sheet provides a visual guide for artists and researchers working on facial animation or speech studies. It includes an Interactive Phoneme to Viseme Chart for English Consonants, categorizing consonants into various viseme groups based on their phoneme characteristics.

### List of Consonants and their Viseme Groups
1. **neutral / silent**: No sound, relaxed
2. **m/b/p viseme group**: m (bilabial, nasal, voiced), b (bilabial, plosive, voiced), p (bilabial, plosive, voiceless)
3. **ʧ / ʤ / ʃ / ʒ viseme group**: ʧ (post-alveolar, affricate, voiceless), ʤ (post-alveolar, affricate, voiced), ʃ (post-alveolar, fricative, voiceless), ʒ (post-alveolar, fricative, voiced)
4. **d / t viseme group**: d (alveolar, plosive, voiced), t (alveolar, plosive, voiceless)
5. **f / v viseme group**: f (labiodental, fricative, voiceless), v (labiodental, fricative, voiced)
6. **g / k viseme group**: g (velar, plosive, voiced), k (velar, plosive, voiceless)
7. **h phoneme**: h (glottal, fricative, voiceless)
8. **l phoneme**: l (alveolar, lateral, voiced)
9. **n phoneme**: n (alveolar, nasal, voiced)
10. **r phoneme**: r (post-alveolar, approximant, voiced)
11. **s / z viseme group**: s (alveolar, fricative, voiceless), z (alveolar, fricative, voiced)
12. **θ / ð (th) viseme group**: θ (dental, fricative, voiceless), ð (dental, fricative, voiced)

### Key Terms Related to Consonants
- **alveolar**: Tip of tongue touches the gum line behind the teeth.
- **bilabial**: Upper and lower lips come together.
- **labiodental**: Lip touches the teeth.
- **dental**: Tongue interacts with teeth.
- **post-alveolar**: Tongue is placed right behind the gum line behind teeth.
- **velar**: Back of tongue touches or is held close to the velum (soft palate).
- **glottal**: Air sound is produced by stopping flow to glottis.

### Relevant Links and Resources
- [Viseme & Speech Reference Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/): Provides detailed descriptions and slow-motion videos for deeper understanding.
- [International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) chart hosted on Cambridge University & Press Assessment](https://www.cambridge.org/features/IPAchart/): Reference for phonetic alphabet.
- [READ POST ON m/b/p SHAPE & ASYMMETRY HERE](https://melindaozel.com/m-b-p-bilabial-visemes/): Detailed post on m/b/p shape and asymmetry.
- [Consulting Services for Phoneme-to-Viseme Mapping](https://melindaozel.com/services/consulting/): Offers consulting services for phoneme-to-viseme mapping.

### Instructions and Important Details
- The webpage provides an interactive chart for English Consonants, categorized by their phoneme and viseme characteristics.
- Users are instructed to hover over target phonemes to view their corresponding viseme poses.
- The phoneme-to-viseme mapping can vary based on the use case, such as simple speech movements or nuanced representations.

### Other Relevant Information
The Viseme Cheat Sheet is designed for artists and researchers working on facial animation or speech studies. It provides a comprehensive visual guide to understanding consonants and their viseme groups, which is crucial for accurate facial animation and speech representation.

Attachments:

## Information about 'neutral silent'

### Explanation
'neutral silent' refers to a viseme that represents a state of no sound and a relaxed facial configuration.

### Purpose
The purpose of identifying 'neutral silent' is to establish a baseline for understanding other visemes and their corresponding phonemes in facial animation and speech studies.

### Key Features
- No sound is produced.
- The facial muscles are in a relaxed state.

### Relevant Links
- [Viseme & Speech Reference Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/) (paywalled)

To utilize the 'neutral silent' viseme, refer to the Viseme Cheat Sheet provided on the webpage. The sheet lists American English phonemes and their corresponding visemes.

browser_content:
## Detailed Information about 'mbp viseme group'

### Explanation
The 'mbp viseme group' refers to a category of phonemes that are visually indistinguishable from one another. Specifically, it includes the phonemes /m/, /b/, and /p/. These phonemes are classified as bilabial, meaning they are produced by bringing both lips together.

* /m/ is a nasal, voiced phoneme, as in the word "masseter".
* /b/ is a plosive, voiced phoneme, as in the word "buccinator".
* /p/ is a plosive, voiceless phoneme, as in the word "pout".

All three phonemes require the lips to close entirely or nearly entirely, making them visually similar.

### Related Resources
For a deeper understanding of the 'mbp viseme group', the following resources are available:
* A detailed post on the 'm/b/p shape & asymmetry' can be found at [READ POST ON m/b/p SHAPE & ASYMMETRY HERE.](https://melindaozel.com/m-b-p-bilabial-visemes/)
* The 'Viseme & Speech Reference Guide' provides more detailed descriptions and slow-motion videos, available at [Viseme& Speech Reference Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/).

### Instructions
To effectively use the 'mbp viseme group' in facial animation or speech studies:
1. Understand that /b/ and /p/ require the lips to part after the initial lip closure to propel air for the plosive sound.
2. Refer to the 'Viseme Cheat Sheet' for a visual guide on the phonemes and their corresponding visemes.

### Contact Information
For tailored help with phoneme-to-viseme mapping, reach out to Melinda Ozel at [https://melindaozel.com/services/consulting/](https://melindaozel.com/services/consulting/).

### People Names
* Melinda Ozel: The author of the 'Viseme Cheat Sheet' and an expert in facial motion and the Facial Action Coding System (FACS).
* Cletus G. Fisher: Coined the term "viseme" in his 1968 paper “[Confusions among visually perceived consonants.](https://pubs.asha.org/doi/10.1044/jshr.1104.796)”

### Key Terms
* **Bilabial**: Upper and lower lips come together.
* **Plosive**: A consonantal sound made by blocking the mouth and then releasing it.
* **Nasal**: A sound made by directing air through the nasal cavity.

### Links
* [Viseme Cheat Sheet](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-cheat-sheet/): A visual guide for artists and researchers working on facial animation or speech studies.
* [Viseme & Speech Reference Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/): A detailed guide with descriptions and slow-motion videos.
* [International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) chart](https://www.cambridge.org/features/IPAchart/): To hear what each phoneme sounds like.

### Address
No physical address is provided on the webpage. However, Melinda Ozel's contact information can be found at [https://melindaozel.com/who-is-melinda-ozel/contact-me/](https://melindaozel.com/who-is-melinda-ozel/contact-me/).

Attachments:

browser_content:
## Viseme Cheat Sheet Details

### What is 'ʧ ʤ ʃ ʒ viseme group' and its purpose?
- The 'ʧ ʤ ʃ ʒ viseme group' refers to a set of phonemes that are visually similar and are often grouped together for the purpose of facial animation or speech studies.

### Viseme Group Details:
- ʧ (as in "chin") - post-alveolar, affricate, voiceless
- ʤ (as in "jaw", "gem") - post-alveolar, affricate, voiced
- ʃ (as in "shine", "spatial") - post-alveolar, fricative, voiceless
- ʒ (as in "genre", "measure") - post-alveolar, fricative, voiced

### Relevant Links and Resources:
- [Viseme & Speech Reference Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/) - a detailed guide with slow-motion videos (paywalled)
- [International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) chart hosted on Cambridge University & Press Assessment](https://www.cambridge.org/features/IPAchart/) - to hear the pronunciation of phonemes
- [Viseme Variability & Gritted Teeth Muted Speech](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-variability-gritted-teeth-muted-speech/) - related reading on viseme variation
- [Consulting Services](https://melindaozel.com/services/consulting/) - for tailored help with phoneme-to-viseme mapping

### Key Features and Important Details:
- The viseme group is used to simplify the representation of speech in facial animation.
- The phonemes in this group are post-alveolar, meaning the tongue is positioned behind the gum line.
- The group includes both affricate and fricative sounds.
- The viseme group is useful for creating more realistic speech movements in animation.

Attachments:

## Viseme Cheat Sheet Details

### What is 'ʧ ʤ ʃ ʒ viseme group' and its purpose?
- The 'ʧ ʤ ʃ ʒ viseme group' refers to a set of phonemes that are visually similar and are often grouped together for the purpose of facial animation or speech studies.

### Viseme Group Details:
- ʧ (as in "chin") - post-alveolar, affricate, voiceless
- ʤ (as in "jaw", "gem") - post-alveolar, affricate, voiced
- ʃ (as in "shine", "spatial") - post-alveolar, fricative, voiceless
- ʒ (as in "genre", "measure") - post-alveolar, fricative, voiced

### Relevant Links and Resources:
- [Viseme & Speech Reference Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/) - a detailed guide with slow-motion videos (paywalled)
- [International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) chart hosted on Cambridge University & Press Assessment](https://www.cambridge.org/features/IPAchart/) - to hear the pronunciation of phonemes

### Key Terms:
- **post-alveolar**: tongue is placed right behind the gum line behind teeth
- **affricate**: a type of consonantal sound that is produced by combining a stop and a fricative
- **fricative**: a type of consonantal sound that is made by directing air through a narrow channel in the vocal tract
- **voiceless**: a sound made without vibration of the vocal cords
- **voiced**: a sound made with vibration of the vocal cords

The 'ʧ ʤ ʃ ʒ viseme group' is useful for creating more realistic speech movements in animation.

- The phoneme ʤ is "as in jaw, gem".
- It is classified as a post-alveolar, affricate, voiced phoneme.
- It belongs to the ʧ / ʤ / ʃ / ʒ viseme group.

semantic_path: https://melindaozel.com/Viseme Cheat Sheet/d t viseme group
browser_content:
## d t viseme group explanation
The d/t viseme group includes the phonemes /d/ and /t/. They are both alveolar plosives, with /d/ being voiced and /t/ being voiceless. Visually, they are considered to be in the same viseme group because they share similar articulatory features.

## links
- [Viseme & Speech Reference Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/) (paywalled)
- [International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) chart hosted on Cambridge University & Press Assessment](https://www.cambridge.org/features/IPAchart/)
- [Cletus G. Fisher's seminal 1968 paper “Confusions among visually perceived consonants.”](https://pubs.asha.org/doi/10.1044/jshr.1104.796)

## instructions
To understand the d/t viseme group, refer to the explanations and examples provided on the webpage. For a deeper dive, consult the Viseme & Speech Reference Guide.

## phone numbers
No phone numbers are available on the webpage.

## people names
- Melinda Ozel
- Cletus G. Fisher

## addresses
No physical addresses are available on the webpage.

## related resources
- [Viseme & Speech Reference Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/)
- [International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) chart](https://www.cambridge.org/features/IPAchart/)
- [Cletus G. Fisher's paper on visually perceived consonants](https://pubs.asha.org/doi/10.1044/jshr.1104.796)

## key features
- The d/t viseme group includes /d/ and /t/ phonemes.
- Both are alveolar plosives.
- /d/ is voiced, while /t/ is voiceless.

## capabilities
The webpage provides a visual guide for artists and researchers working on facial animation or speech studies, including an interactive phoneme to viseme chart.

## important details
- The d/t viseme group is characterized by the tongue touching the alveolar ridge.
- The main difference between /d/ and /t/ lies in their voicing, not in their visual articulation.

browser_content:
## Viseme Cheat Sheet Summary

### Explanation of 'f / v viseme group'
The 'f / v viseme group' refers to phonemes that are categorized as labiodental, fricative sounds. This includes sounds like /f/ and /v/. The viseme group is characterized by the way the lips and teeth interact to produce these sounds. For example, 'face' represents the /f/ sound, and 'viseme' represents the /v/ sound.

### Purpose
The purpose of identifying viseme groups like 'f / v' is to aid in facial animation and speech studies by simplifying the representation of speech-related mouth and lip movements.

### Relevant Links and Resources
* [Visemes & Articulation Variation](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-variability-gritted-teeth-muted-speech/): Further reading on viseme variability.
* [Viseme & Speech Reference Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/): A more detailed guide that includes slow-motion videos.
* [International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) chart hosted on Cambridge University & Press Assessment](https://www.cambridge.org/features/IPAchart/): A resource to hear the pronunciation of phonemes.

### Key Features and Capabilities
- Labiodental: Involves the lower lip and upper teeth.
- Fricative: Produced by directing air through a narrow channel.
- Voiceless (/f/): No vocal cord vibration.
- Voiced (/v/): With vocal cord vibration.

### Other Relevant Information
The Viseme Cheat Sheet provides detailed information on various viseme groups, including:
- 'm/b/p' viseme group: Bilabial and plosive sounds.
- 'ʧ / ʤ / ʃ  / ʒ' viseme group: Post-alveolar affricate and fricative sounds.
- 'd / t' viseme group: Alveolar plosive sounds.
- 'g / k' viseme group: Velar plosive sounds.
- 'h' phoneme: Glottal fricative sound.

The page includes interactive slides with hover-over images to reveal phoneme details and phoneme states.

## f / v viseme group

### Explanation
The f / v viseme group refers to a category of phonemes that are visually indistinguishable from one another. Specifically, the phonemes /f/ and /v/ share the same visually observable articulation, making them part of the same viseme.

### Purpose
The purpose of identifying viseme groups like f / v is to aid in facial animation and speech studies by simplifying the representation of speech-related mouth and lip movements.

### Key Features
* /f/ and /v/ are labiodental fricatives, meaning they involve the lower lip touching the top teeth.
* /f/ is voiceless, while /v/ is voiced.
* Despite their acoustic differences, /f/ and /v/ are visually similar, making them part of the same viseme group.

### Related Resources
* [Viseme & Speech Reference Guide](https://melindaozel.com/viseme-speech-guide/): A more detailed guide that includes slow-motion videos.
